item.title: Bethany Nowviskie on "Addressing the idea of "the good" in digital humanities?"
item.dc:creator: Bethany Nowviskie
item.description:
You might look closely at John Unsworth's piece in DHQ on "The Making of 'Our Cultural Commonwealth,'" the NSF's 2003 blue-ribbon task force report on humanities cyberinfrastructure -- and at the report itself.

In general, I hear the phrase "the (or a) public good" used with increasing frequency in the context of DH -- especially as more importance is placed on "the public humanities."

On that, I like this piece by Kathy Woodward in Daedalus: "The Future of the Humanities: in the Present and in Public."

item.title: mlaux on "Addressing the idea of "the good" in digital humanities?"
item.dc:creator: mlaux
item.description:
Dear all,

I have been researching materials pertaining to “the good,” “goodness,” and “the good in society” in all disciplines and fields of study: science, engineering, social sciences, law, humanities, architecture, art, and business. Drawing on your respective expertise, are there particular sources you would suggest as helpful or that address this topic in digital humanities? Helpful materials could include art, articles, court cases, films, journal articles, literature, monographs, music, websites, etc.

Thank you
Michelle Laux
